metadata.title: Buckling analysis of functionally graded rectangular nano-plate based on nonlocal exponential shear deformation theory

sections.text:
In this article, buckling response of functionally graded nano-plate based on exponential shear deformation theory is presented. The theory presented herein is built upon the classical plate theory. In this displacement-based, refined shear deformation theory, an exponential functions are used in terms of thickness co-ordinate to include the effect of transverse shear deformation and rotary inertia. The number of unknown displacement variables in the proposed theory are same as that in first order shear deformation theory. Nonlocal elasticity theory is employed to investigate effects of small scale on buckling of the functionally graded rectangular nano-plate. The material properties of the plate are assumed to vary according to the Power Law form in the thickness direction. The governing equations and corresponding boundary conditions are derived by implementing Hamilton’s principle. To show the accuracy of the formulations, our research results in specific cases are compared with available results in the literature and a good agreement will be observed. Finally, the effect of various parameters such as nonlocal parameter, Power Law indexes, aspect ratio, and the thickness ratio on the non-dimensional critical buckling load of rectangular FG nano-plates are presented and discussed in detail.
Keywords: Buckling, Functionally graded, Rectangular nano-plate, Exponential shear deformation theory, Navier type solution.
1. Introduction
Nanostructures are widely used in micro- and nano-scale devices and systems such as biosensors, atomic force, microscopes, micro-electro-mechanical systems (MEMS) and nanoelectro-mechanical systems (NEMS) due to their superior mechanical, chemical, and electronic
properties.In such applications, small scale effects are often observed. These effects can be captured using size-dependent continuum mechanics such as strain gradient theory[1-3], modified couple stress theories[4-6], and nonlocal elasticity theory [7]. Among these theories, the nonlocal elasticity theory is initiated by Eringen is the most commonly used theory. Unlike the local theories, which assume that the stress at a point is a function of strain at that point, the nonlocal elasticity theory assumes that the stress at a point is a function of strains at all points in the continuum. Functionally graded materials (FGMs) are the new generation of novel composite materials in the family of engineering composites, whose properties are varied smoothly in the spatial direction microscopically to improve the overall structural performance. These materials offer great promise in high temperature environments, for example, wear-resistant linings for handling large heavy abrasive ore particles, rocket heat shields, heat exchanger tubes, thermoelectric generators, heat engine components, plasma facings for fusion reactors, and electrically insulating metal/ceramic joints and also these are widely used in many structural applications such as mechanics, civil engineering, optical, electronic, chemical, biomedical, energy sources, nuclear, automotive fields, and ship building industries to minimize thermo mechanical mismatch in metal-ceramic bonding. In recent years, the application of FGMs has broadly been spread in micro- and nano-scale devices and systems such as thin films [8,9], atomic force microscopes [10], micro- and nano-electro-mechanical systems (MEMS and NEMS) [11,12].Most structures, irrespective of their use, will be subjected to dynamic loads during their operational life. Increased use of nano FGMs in various structural applications such as thermonano-actuators, heat-nano-sensors, pressure sensors and etc., necessitates the development of accurate theoretical models to predict their response. In recent years, the buckling of functionally graded materials for nano-plate has been studied extensively. Pradhan[13] is reformulated higher order shear deformation theory using the nonlocal differential constitutive relations of Eringen to study the buckling characteristics of grapheme sheets.Pouresmaeeli et al. [14] are investigated an analytical approach for free vibration analysis of all simply-supported edges double-orthotropic nano-plates. The two nano-plates are assumed to be bonded by an internal elastic medium and surrounded by external elastic foundation. The governing equations are derived based on the nonlocal theory.And the expressions of the natural frequencies are proposed in an explicit form. Kiani [15] is studiedthe vibration of elastic thin nano-plates traversed by a moving nanoparticle involving Coulomb friction by using the nonlocal continuum theory of Eringen. The eigen
function technique and the Laplace transform method are employed to solve the governing equations of the nano-plate. Shahidi et al. [16] arepresented a nonlocal continuum model based on the Eringen’s theory which is developedfor vibration analysis of orthotropic nano-plates with arbitrary variation in thickness. Variational principle and Ritz functions are employed to calculate the size dependent natural frequencies of non-uniform nano-plates on the basis of nonlocal classical plate theory(NCLPT). Thai and Choi [17] arepresented size-dependent functionally graded material for Kirchhoff and Mindlin plate models evaluated the size effect, geometric nonlinearity, and material variation through the thickness of the plate. The equations of motion are derived from Hamilton’s principle based on the modified couple stress theory, von Karman nonlinear strains, and Power Law variation of material through the thickness. Analytical solutions for the static bending, buckling, and free vibration problems are presented for a simply supported plate to bring out the effects of material length scale parameter on the deflection, buckling load, and frequency. Rahmani and Pedram [18] are investigated Timoshenko beam theory that applies the size dependent effects in functionally graded material (FGM) beam. The material properties of FG nano-beams are considered to vary based on the thickness according to the Power Law. The equations of motion according to Eringen nonlocal theory, using Hamilton’s principle are derived and a closed-form solution is presented for vibration behavior of the proposed model. The nonlocal elasticity theory contains a material length scale parameter that can apply the size effect in an FG material. Mokhtar et al. [19] are reported thermal buckling analyses of S-FGM using first order shear deformation theory. Material properties are varied continuously in the thickness direction according to a Sigmond distribution. The thermal buckling behaviors under uniform, linear and sinusoidal temperature rise are analyzed according to thickness. In addition, the effects of temperature field, volume fraction distributions, and system geometric parameters are investigated. Reddy et al. [20] are presented analytical formulations and solutions for buckling analysis of simply supported functionally graded plates (FGPs) using higher order shear deformation theory (HSDT) without enforcing zero transverse shear stresses on the top and bottom surfaces of the plate. It does not required for shear correction factors and transverse shear stresses to vary parabolically across the thickness. Solutions are obtained for FGPs in closed-form using Navier technique. Hosseini-Hashemi et al. [21] are presented an exact solution for linear buckling of in-plane loaded isotropic rectangular Mindlin plates with different boundary conditions. The novelty of the paper is that the analytical
closed-form solution is developed without any use of approximation for a combination of six different boundary conditions; specifically, two opposite edges are simply supported and any of the other two edges can be simply supported, clamped or free. Khorshidi [22] and HosseiniHashemi et al. [23] are investigated the acoustic radiation of a vibrating rectangular Mindlin plates in different combinations of classical boundary condition. A set of exact close-form equations is given for the first time, using the so-called Mindlin plate theory (a first-order shear deformation theory), for plates having two opposite edges that are simply supported. HosseiniHashemi et al. [24, 25] are developed an exact closed-form solution for the free vibration of piezoelectric coupled thick circular/annular FGPs subjected to different boundary conditions on the basis of the Mindlin’s first-order shear deformation theory. Hosseini-Hashemi et al. [26], Fadaee et al. [27], Es'haghi et al. [28], and Hosseini-Hashemi et al. [29] are developed an exact closed-form procedure for free vibration analysis of functionally graded moderately thick cylindrical shell, functionally graded spherical shell, piezoelectric FGM circular plates, and moderately thick rectangular plates, respectively. Hosseini-Hashemi et al. [30] are presented an exact analytical solution for free vibration of functionally graded circular/annular Mindlinnanoplates via nonlocal elasticity. Sayyad and Ghugal [31] are analyzed the bending and free vibrationof thick isotropic rectangular plates by using exponential shear deformation theory for the bi-directional bending. Meziane et al. [32] presented an analytical solution for the buckling and free vibration of exponentially graded sandwich plates under various boundary conditions. In this paper, an efficient and simple refined shear deformation theory was presented. The displacement field of the theory was chosen based on nonlinear variations in the in-plane displacements through the thickness of the plate. By dividing the transverse displacement into the bending and shear parts and making further assumptions, the number of unknowns and equations of motion of the theory was reduced. Equations of motion were derived from Hamilton’s principle.Yahia et al. [33] analyzed the Wave propagation in functionally graded plates with porosities using various higher-order shear deformation plate theories. In this work, the developed refined plate theories have fewer number of unknowns and equations of motion than the first-order shear deformation theory, but accounts for the transverse shear deformation effects without requiring shear correction factors. The rule of mixture was modified to describe and approximate material properties of the functionally graded plates with porosity phases. The governing equations of the wave propagation in the functionally graded plate were derived by
employing the Hamilton's principle.Tounsi et al. [34] studied a refined trigonometric shear deformation theory (RTSDT) for thermoelastic bending of functionally graded sandwich plates. In this work, unlike any other theory, the number of unknown functions involved was only four, as against five in case of other shear deformation theories. The theory presented was variationally consistent, did not require shear correction factor, the displacement components were expressed by trigonometric series representation through the plate thickness to develop a two-dimensional theory and gives rise to transverse shear stress variation such that the transverse shear stresses vary parabolically across the thickness satisfying shear stress free surface conditions. The sandwich with homogeneous face sheet and FGM core was considered. Material properties of the FGM core were assumed to vary according to a power law distribution in terms of the volume fractions of the constituents.Bourada et al. [35] presented a new simple shear and normal deformations theory for functionally graded beams. In this paper, a new higher order shear deformation model was developed for static and free vibration analysis of functionally graded beams. The theory account for higher-order variation of transverse shear strain through the depth of the beam and satisfies the zero traction boundary conditions on the surfaces of the beam without using shear correction factors. The material properties of the functionally graded beam were assumed to vary according to power law distribution of the volume fraction of the constituents. Based on the higher-order shear deformation beam theory, the equations of motion were derived from Hamilton’s principle. Navier type solution method was used to obtain frequencies.Hamidi et al. [36] investigated a sinusoidal plate theory with 5-unknowns and stretching effect for thermo mechanical bending of functionally graded sandwich plates. In this research, a simple but accurate sinusoidal plate theory for the thermo mechanical bending analysis of functionally graded sandwich plates is presented. The main advantage of this approach is that, in addition to incorporating the thickness stretching effect, it deals with only 5 unknowns as the first order shear deformation theory (FSDT), instead of 6 as in the well-known conventional sinusoidal plate theory (SPT). Hebaliet al. [37] considereda new quasi-3D hyperbolic shear deformation theory for the static and free vibration analysis of functionally graded plates.Bounouara et al. [38] developed A nonlocal zeroth-order shear deformation theory for free vibration of functionally graded nanoscale plates resting on elastic foundation. The objective of this work was to present a zeroth-order shear deformation theory for free vibration analysis of functionally graded (FG) nanoscale plates resting on elastic foundation. The model
takes into consideration the influences of small scale and the parabolic variation of the transverse shear strains across the thickness of the nanoscale plate and thus, it avoids the employ use of shear correction factors. Chaht et al. [39] studied the bending and buckling behaviors of sizedependent nanobeams made of functionally graded materials (FGMs) including the thickness stretching effect. The size-dependent FGM nanobeam was investigated on the basis of the nonlocal continuum model. The nonlocal elastic behavior was described by the differential constitutive model of Eringen, which enables the present model to become effective in the analysis and design of nanostructures.Khorshidi et al. [40] presented an analytical solution for the free vibrations of of functionally graded rectangular nanoplatesbased on an exponential shear deformation theory. In this study an exponential functions were used in terms of thickness coordinate to include the effect of transverse shear deformation and rotary inertia. Nonlocal elasticity theory was employed to investigate effect of small scale on natural frequency of the functionally graded rectangular nanoplate. The govering equations and corresponding boundary conditions were derived by implementing Hamilton’s principle. In the present research, for the first time, buckling of functionally graded nano-plates is investigated based on theexponential shear deformation theory and nonlocal elasticity theory. The former includes effects of transverse shear deformation and rotary inertia. The displacement field of the theory contains three variables such as in the FSDT of plates. The theory is shown to be simple and more effective for the free vibration analysis of FGM nano-plates. It is assumed that the material properties varybased on the thickness according to the Power Law distribution. Navier solution is used to study the buckling of functionally graded nano-plates. To validate the accuracy of the results of this analysis, Since the results of nano-plates made of FGM are not available in the literature, so the authors have broken the validation into two separate parts; in the first part, validatean isotropic rectangular nano-plate, and in the second part, do the same for an FGM one, and the results will be compared with solutions found in the literature. Finally numerical result for FGM nano-plate will be presented and the influences of nonlocal parameters, Power Law indexes, aspect ratio, and the thickness ratio on the non-dimensional critical buckling load of rectangular FGM nano-plates will be presented and discussed in detail.The results of the present work may be used as bench marks for future works.
2. Theoretical formulations
Consider a rectangular FG-nano-plate of length a , width b , and total thickness h and composed of functionally graded materials based on thickness as shown in Figure 1. The properties of the nano-plate are assumed to vary through the thickness of the nano-plate with a Power Law distribution of the volume fractions of two materials between the two surfaces. In fact, the top surface ( / 2z h ) of the nano-plate is ceramic-rich whereas the bottom surface ( / 2z h  ) is metal-rich. Poisson’s ratio  is assumed to be constant and is fixed as 0.3 throughout the analysis. Young’s modulus and mass density are assumed to vary continuously through the nano-plate thickness as[24]:

2.2. Assumptions made in the proposed theory 1. The displacement components and are the in-plane displacements of middle surface in and
directions respectively and is the deflection of middle surface in direction. The magnitude of deflection is not of the same order as the thickness of the plate and are small respect to the plate thickness 2. The in-plane displacement and includes three parts: a) A displacement component equivalent to displacement in classical plate theory. b) Displacement component due to shear deformation which is assumed to be exponential in nature with respect to thickness coordinate. c) The shear strains in direction, are zero in top and bottom of plates. 3. The deflection in direction is assumed to be a function of and coordinates. 4. The plate is subjected to transverse load only. (a/b=0.5, 1.0) and thickness to length ratios (h/a=0.01, 0.1) on the non-dimensional critical buckling load ratios are investigated. Figure 2 shows variations of the buckling load ratio with nondimensional nonlocal parameter for various aspect ratios with / 0.1h a  . It can be seen that an increase of aspect ratio (a/b), leads to a decrease of buckling load ratio of the Nano-plate, and also by increasing the non-dimensional nonlocal parameters, the buckling load ratio decreases, because by increasing in the nonlocal parameter, the strain energy decreases, and it causes the decrease of plates rigidity. Figure 3 shows variations of critical buckling load with nondimensional nonlocal parameter for various length to thickness ratios with / 1a b  , and it can be observed that an increase of the length to thickness ratio causes an increase of the effect of the nonlocal parameter on the buckling load.Because the effect of shear deformation is significant for a length to thickness ratio of less than 10 and diminishes with an increase of length to thickness ratio.
3.2. FGM plate In Tables 3 and 4, there is a comparison for the non-dimensional critical buckling load 2 3( / )cr mN N a E h , with higher-order theory[20], for the rectangular 2 3Al/Al O FGM plates, that are simply supported at all edges, and subjected to uniaxial and biaxial compressions. And a very good agreement between the results can be observed. Effects of length to thickness ratio (a/h) on nondimensional critical buckling load under biaxial compression for a simply supported FG plate and various material variation parameter (g), is plotted in Figure 4, and it can learned that the effect of shear deformation is significant for a thickness to length ratio less than 10 and it diminishes with an increase of length to thickness ratio. Figure 5 shows effects of aspect ratio (a/b) on nondimensional critical buckling load under biaxial compression for a FG plate and the various material variation parameter, and it is clear that an increase of the aspect ratio, results an increase of the nondimensional critical buckling load.
4. Result and discussion
In this section, the FGM nano-plateis made of Aluminum/Alumina ( 2 3Al/Al O ), which properties are listed in Table 1, is investigated. Tables 5 and 6 show the non-dimensional critical buckling
load 2 3( / )cr mN N a E h for an FGM Nano-plate subjected to uniaxial compression and biaxial compression, respectively. And the effects of various values of non-dimensional nonlocal
parameter ( /a =0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4), aspect ratios (a/b=0.5, 1), length to thickness ratios
(a/h=5, 10), and Power Low index (g=0, 0.5, 1, 2, 5, 10) on the non-dimensional critical buckling load are investigated and discussed in details. It can be observed in the Tables 5 and 6 that the buckling load decreases by increasing the nonlocal parameter, due to a decrease of the strain energy, and also by increasing the aspect ratio, the critical buckling load increases, since, the plate considering here is assumed to be simply supported at all edges, a decrease in length with a constant width, causes a decrease of the degree of freedom (DOF) of the plate, and an increase of the stiffness and frequency parameter. Also, it is realized that by increasethe nonlocal parameter, the rate of the variation of nondimensional critical buckling load, will decreasing, because an increase of the nonlocal parametercauses thestrain energy to decrease, and consequently causes the plates rigidity to decrease.Bycomparing Tables 6 and 5, it is found out that the critical buckling loads in uniaxial compression are larger than in biaxial compression. Also, Figure 6 is plotted to better illustrate the effect of different parameters on non-dimensional critical buckling load. According to Figure 6, for lower Power Law index, the rate of the non-dimensional critical buckling load, is higher, and the effect of the non-dimensional nonlocal parameter on the nondimensional critical buckling loadis significant, and diminishes with an increase ofPower Low index because by increasing in the Power Law index, the properties of the plate approachthose of Metals, and its stiffness decreases, thus,the non-dimensional critical buckling load decreases.
5. Conclusion The Navier method is applied to the Buckling of functionally graded rectangular nano-plates. The formulations are based on theexponential shear deformation theory using nonlocal elasticity theory. Hamilton’s principle is used to derive the equations of motion and the associated boundary conditions. Comparison cases reported in the literature for simply supported rectangular FG Nano-plates, demonstrate the high stability and accuracy of the present solution. The present work demonstrates the effects of variations of nonlocal parameter, thickness to length ratio, Power Law indexes and aspect ratio on the critical values of an FG Nano-plate. this
shows that the critical buckling load decreases by increasing the value of the nonlocal parameter, and also increasing the Power Law index causes the non-dimensional critical buckling to decrease, moreover, anincrease of aspect ratio increases the critical buckling load, and an increase of the length to thickness causes an increase of the critical buckling load. All analytical results presented here can provide other research groups with a reliable source to check their analytical and numerical solutions.

Highlights
 Studied buckling of a rectangular FG-Nano-plate using nonlocal exponential shear deformation
plate theory (ESDT).
 Derived the governing equations of motion of a rectangular FG-Nano-plate based on nonlocal
ESDT by using the Hamilton’s principle.
 Used Navier type solution to obtain Critical buckling load of FG-Nano-plate.  Comparison of local and nonlocal natural frequency parameters of FG-Nano-plate for different
small scale parameters, power low index, aspect ratios and thickness ratios.
 Provided a simple analytical method that can be easily solved by researchers and engineers.

metadata.abstractText: In this article, buckling response of functionally graded nano-plate based on exponential shear deformation theory is presented. The theory presented herein is built upon the classical plate theory. In this displacement-based, refined shear deformation theory, an exponential functions are used in terms of thickness co-ordinate to include the effect of transverse shear deformation and rotary inertia. The number of unknown displacement variables in the proposed theory are same as that in first order shear deformation theory. Nonlocal elasticity theory is employed to investigate effects of small scale on buckling of the functionally graded rectangular nano-plate. The material properties of the plate are assumed to vary according to the Power Law form in the thickness direction. The governing equations and corresponding boundary conditions are derived by implementing Hamilton’s principle. To show the accuracy of the formulations, our research results in specific cases are compared with available results in the literature and a good agreement will be observed. Finally, the effect of various parameters such as nonlocal parameter, Power Law indexes, aspect ratio, and the thickness ratio on the non-dimensional critical buckling load of rectangular FG nano-plates are presented and discussed in detail.
